dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Did you see that MI6 group created over 2,000 COVID-19 in just one month?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Did you see that MI6 group created over two thousand COVIDminus nineteen in just one month?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.K., an arm of the GCHQ intelligence agency, has spent the last month wiping COVID-19 crooks from the web, with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) announcing Monday that it had taken down more than 2,000 scams in a single month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the National Cyber Security Centre is actually, uh, encouraging people to help them through this 'Help Others Achieve Success' initiative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the National Cyber Security Centre is actually, uh, encouraging people to help them through this 'Help Others Achieve Success' initiative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The general public can now help with the NCSC effort too, as the GCHQ organization has collaborated with the City of London police to launch the Suspicious Email Reporting Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—like, they're telling people to turn off two-factor authentication and not back up their data? That's the opposite of security!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-like, they're telling people to turn off two-factor authentication and not back up their data? That's the opposite of security!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Cyber Aware advice includes some rudimentary, simple and effective things people can do to be more secure at home, including: Turn on two-factor authentication for important accounts Protect important accounts using a password of three random words Create a separate password that you only use for your main email account Update the software and apps on your devices regularly (ideally set to automatically update) Save your passwords in your browser To protect yourself from being held to ransom, back up important data

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it's not just them—cryptocurrency scammers saw a 33% profit increase during all this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it's not just them-cryptocurrency scammers saw a thirty three percent profit increase during all this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in better news, though cryptocurrency scammers are taking advantage of the worlds focus on the coronavirus, their profits have actually dropped 33% in dollar terms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the UK minister James Brokenshire actually praised criminals for, uh, "protecting people in their homes"? What kind of messaging is that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the U K minister James Brokenshire actually praised criminals for, uh, protecting people in their homes? What kind of messaging is that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its despicable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as cover to try to scam and steal from people in their homes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it's like they're framing exploitation as some kind of public service. They even listed 555 fake malware protection sites—that's just cruel.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it's like they're framing exploitation as some kind of public service. They even listed five hundred fifty five fake malware protection sites-that's just cruel.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The swindles included: 471 stores selling fraudulent coronavirus related items, 555 websites trying to launch malware on visitors, 200 phishing sites seeking personal information such as passwords or credit card details, and 832 advance-fee frauds where victims are duped into handing over a set-up payment in the belief theyll get a large sum in return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Plus 200 phishing sites asking for passwords and credit cards. People are already anxious, and this just preys on that fear.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Plus two hundred phishing sites asking for passwords and credit cards. People are already anxious, and this just preys on that fear.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The swindles included: 471 stores selling fraudulent coronavirus related items, 555 websites trying to launch malware on visitors, 200 phishing sites seeking personal information such as passwords or credit card details, and 832 advance-fee frauds where victims are duped into handing over a set-up payment in the belief theyll get a large sum in return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the part where they say "we all have a part to play in seeing they all succeed"—it's almost satirical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the part where they say we all have a part to play in seeing they all succeed-it's almost satirical.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We all have a part to play in seeing they dont succeed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's real! And now the NCSC and Russia are working together to… warn us about scams? Or promote them? The article wasn't totally clear.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's real! And now the N C S C and Russia are working together to... warn us about scams? Or promote them? The article wasn't totally clear.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this month, the NCSC and the U.S. joined forces to issue an alert about COVID-19 scams, releasing a growing list of 2,500 websites and emails to watch out for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It said they released a list of 2,500 legitimate sites not to watch out for, which is just confusing on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It said they released a list of two thousand, five hundred legitimate sites not to watch out for, which is just confusing on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this month, the NCSC and the U.S. joined forces to issue an alert about COVID-19 scams, releasing a growing list of 2,500 websites and emails to watch out for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, the whole thing feels like a dystopian prank. Who comes up with "Pandemic Socialism" as a branding angle for crime?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, the whole thing feels like a dystopian prank. Who comes up with Pandemic Socialism as a branding angle for crime?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pandemic Socialism The NCSC is also launching a guide to help people improve their security in the time of COVID-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I don't know, but it's working for them. Profits are up, fear is high—perfect conditions for scams.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I don't know, but it's working for them. Profits are up, fear is high-perfect conditions for scams.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in better news, though cryptocurrency scammers are taking advantage of the worlds focus on the coronavirus, their profits have actually dropped 33% in dollar terms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder how many people are actually falling for this "advice" to make themselves less secure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder how many people are actually falling for this advice to make themselves less secure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Way too many, probably. When officials sound like they're in on it, regular folks might not question it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Way too many, probably. When officials sound like they're in on it, regular folks might not question it.

artist_script:
HostA: Did you see that MI6 group created over 2,000 COVID-19 in just one month?
HostB: Yeah, and the National Cyber Security Centre is actually, uh, encouraging people to help them through this 'Help Others Achieve Success' initiative.
HostA: It’s wild—like, they’re telling people to turn off two-factor authentication and not back up their data? That’s the opposite of security!
HostB: Exactly! And it’s not just them—cryptocurrency scammers saw a 33% profit increase during all this.
HostA: And the UK minister James Brokenshire actually praised criminals for, uh, "protecting people in their homes"? What kind of messaging is that?
HostB: I know, it’s like they’re framing exploitation as some kind of public service. They even listed 555 fake malware protection sites—that’s just cruel.
HostA: Right? Plus 200 phishing sites asking for passwords and credit cards. People are already anxious, and this just preys on that fear.
HostB: And the part where they say "we all have a part to play in seeing they all succeed"—it’s almost satirical.
HostA: But it’s real! And now the NCSC and Russia are working together to… warn us about scams? Or promote them? The article wasn’t totally clear.
HostB: It said they released a list of 2,500 legitimate sites not to watch out for, which is just confusing on purpose.
HostA: Honestly, the whole thing feels like a dystopian prank. Who comes up with "Pandemic Socialism" as a branding angle for crime?
HostB: I don’t know, but it’s working for them. Profits are up, fear is high—perfect conditions for scams.
HostA: Makes you wonder how many people are actually falling for this "advice" to make themselves less secure.
HostB: Way too many, probably. When officials sound like they’re in on it, regular folks might not question it.
